dt: {bc}to consent to carry out for a person {bc}allow fulfillment of
{bc}to permit as a right, privilege, or favor
{bc}to give the possession or title of by a deed

dt.t: I {wi}grant{/wi} you that the house is not in perfect condition.

pt: {sc}grant{/sc} {sc}concede{/sc} {sc}vouchsafe{/sc} {sc}accord{/sc} {sc}award{/sc} mean to give as a favor or a right. {sc}grant{/sc} implies giving to a claimant or petitioner something that could be withheld.
{sc}concede{/sc} implies yielding something reluctantly in response to a rightful or compelling claim.

pt.t: even her critics {it}concede{/it} she can be charming

pt: {sc}vouchsafe{/sc} implies granting something as a courtesy or an act of gracious condescension.

pt.t: {it}vouchsafed{/it} the secret to only a few chosen disciples

pt: {sc}accord{/sc} implies giving to another what is due or proper.

pt.t: {it}accorded{/it} all the honors befitting a head of state

pt: {sc}award{/sc} implies giving what is deserved or merited usually after a careful weighing of pertinent factors.

pt.t: {it}awarded{/it} the company a huge defense contract

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}granter, graanter{/it}, from Vulgar Latin {it}*credentare{/it}, from Latin {it}credent-, credens{/it}, present participle of {it}credere{/it} to believe {ma}{mat|creed|}{/ma}
shortdef: to consent to carry out for a person : allow fulfillment of
to permit as a right, privilege, or favor
to bestow or transfer formally; specifically : to give the possession or title of by a deed
